results.title: Setting the scene: landscape spaces (Chris Kennedy and Stephen Curtis)
results.brief_description: Interviews with Chris Kennedy and Stephen Curtis, Australian production designers on their work. Chris Kennedy talks about the two different approaches he took for two films, the building of a town in The Proposition and finding already existing locations for The Road. Stephen Curtis talks about his approach to production designing on his work on Bedevil and Night Cries. Prodcued by AFTRS and ACMI for ACMI’s Setting the Scene exhibition.

results.title: Zea
results.creator_credit: Andre Leduc, Jean-Jacques Leduc, Robert Forget and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A superb visual trick that will mystify its audience, this animated film transforms the commonplace into magic. The film presented a serious technical challenge because the subject was both elusive and explosive. A film to watch, enjoy and laugh about. (Awards: Cannes; Chicago; Elmhurst; Columbus; Paris; Genie, Toronto.) Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Tree that remembers (D)
results.creator_credit: Masoud Raouf and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1992 a young Iranian student and an ex-prisoner of war under the Ayatollah’s regime during the 80’s, hanged himself on the outskirts of a small town in Canada. Director Masoud Raouf, also an ex-prisoner under the Ayatollah regime has sought to address and understand the inherent long-term issues surrounding the survival of ex-political prisoners and asylum seekers, raising issues of cultural integration and disparity between Western cultures and refugees generally whilst giving air to subjects usually silent within Western communities. A group of former prisoners in Iran elucidate on their personal experiences describing the horrors of torture and imprisonment and the means in which they survived spiritually throughout their detainment. “Boxing” a form of solitary confinement is described in detail with its psychological effect - a form of torture that mimics the corpse in order to break the spirit.

results.title: The Town mouse and the country mouse
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Evelyn Lambert’s well-known style of animation using paper figures and brightly coloured backgrounds, based on an Aesop fable. Tells the simple story of two mice with different lifestyles and suggests that it is far better to live simply and in peace than live in luxury amidst danger

results.title: Vision in mathematics: motion geometry
results.brief_description: Reviews and illustrates three isometric plane transformations (translation, reflection, rotation). Examines some combinations of these operations and includes tables to show the final results.

results.title: Virgin and the Gypsy
results.brief_description: D.H. Lawrence’s famous classic of two debutantes, fresh out of finishing school, one ready to rebel against her father who is the local vicar, the other girl not yet ready to face the world. They meet a gypsy girl who changes their Victorian lives forever.

results.title: Violence on the screen
results.creator_credit: Cathy Johnstone and Video Education Australia
results.brief_description: The issue about whether violence on the screen and in the media influences the behaviour of the community, especially children, is a contentious one. This program, comprising of two videos - ‘I wrote to Steven Spielberg’ and ‘Bobo dolls and copy cats’, as well as video support notes, attempts to provide a well rounded introduction to the complexities of the debate. Many questions are raised and discussed, but it should be noted that due to the complex nature of the subject, a definitive answer cannot be reached. The program discusses the difference between real, fictional and implied violence. Discusses the notion of intent, including the difficult areas of comedy and cartoon violence, as well as the impact of television news. It introduces the idea that one effect of viewing violence may be an altered perception of the amount of violence in the world. It discusses the role of Australia’s film and television classification system; asks whether violence is always bad, and asks students to consider whether children are an especially susceptible audience. It also introduces the notion that violence in the media may serve cultural, psychological or historical needs, and asks students to consider whether it’s violence in the media or other factors in people’s lives that are more important in determining actions. Suitable for middle to senior secondary school students in Media Studies, English, and related Studies of Society and Environment.

results.title: Violence in the Cinema.....Part 1
results.creator_credit: George Miller, Byron Kennedy, Acta Scienta and Warlok Films
results.brief_description: A graphic satire on the representation of violence in the cinema, this early work by George Miller has “psychologist and media critic”, Dr. Edgar Fine, providing an academic account on the various theories around this subject. What starts as a fairly didactic and dry discourse on violence in the cinema takes a turn for the gruesomely demonstrative. Brutal acts are performed in visceral detail. This short by Miller was also his first collaboration with producer Byron Kennedy, whom he met at the University of New South Wales. The success of this collaboration led them to form the production company Kennedy Miller and to embody their fascination with violence in the feature film, ‘Mad Max’ (1979).
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Miller, Byron Kennedy, Acta Scienta and Warlok Films

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 9 & 10
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel 4, Malone Gill Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: The power of the purse recounts the rise of Bordeaux as the prime wine producing area of France in the eighteenth century. Massive investment by the nouveaux riches led to the rise of Chateaux Latour, Lafite and Margaux and others who based their success on well-drained soil and insistence on the latest and best cellar techniques. “The devastator” describes the catastrophic effect on the French wine industry of phylloxera which wiped out almost all of the vineyards. Scientific investigations by Pasteur and Planchon solved the problem and introduced new techniques to viticulture.
